PROGRAM OFFERING PROGRAM OFFERING
Titles LITTLE ORCHESTRA SOCIETY
CONCERTS, 1956-57 SEASON
Type; Music with commentary
Time: Varied from 90:00 to 120:00
No.: 8 programs
Origin: Little Orchestra Society-WNYC
Audience: General
Serial Number: 57-23
Release Date: Issue 14 (April 7)
IMPORTANT: As in past years, the Little Orchestra Society has had to honor demands
of various unions and artists involved in presenting these concerts
regarding a date of expiry for the rights governing the broadcast of
this series or any programs from it. This year the date of expiry is
October 1, 1957. No program from this series may be broadcast after
that date.
This gives each station about six months to schedule and air a series
lasting eight weeks. Therefore, we strongly urge that all stations
honor this request.
These are the same concerts given by the Little Orchestra Society in Town Hall
with two differences: the introduction of young artists as some of the soloists,
and brief talks on the unfamiliar music by David Randolph, Music Commentator for
Radio Station WNYC, New York. The conductor for all concerts is Thomas Scherman.
Program 1 - Issue 14
The first concert will be devoted to a "glowingly Spanish" opera, Goyescas, by
Granados, based upon famous paintings of Goya. It was last produced in the United
States by the Mstropolitan Opera forty years ago. Heading the cast will be a young
Spanish soprano, Pilar Lorengar, who has had sensational receptions in every music
capital of Europe. This concert will be her bow in the United States, and to
support her three well known artists have been employed: Martial Singher, MLgnon
Dunn and Davis Cunningham. The New York Concert Choir will serve as chorus.
Program 2 - Issue 15
This concert will be a good example of one of the important aspects of these Dress
Rehearsals: it will serve to introduce a young baritone, Jonathan Kinsler, to a
perceptive audience that can help give him the wider reputation his gifts deserve.
He will sing "a fervent religious miniature," the best known solo cantata of J. S.
Bach, "Ich will den ICreuzstab gerne tragen." Schubert’s gay Viennese Symphony No. 6
will round out the program, together with the "neglected" Scherzo Fantastique by
Josef Suk, a Czechoslovakian composer who was a pupil of Antonin Dvorak. This
marks the first performance of the Suk work in the United States.
Program 3 - Issue 16
An all-French program, also introducing a young artist, Lorin Hollander, the
remarkable 12-year-old pianist who appeared last year in the Society’s Children’s
Concerts. He will play Ravel’s Piano Concerto in G major. There will also be the
courtly 18th century Air de Ballet of Rameau and a symphony by Bizet.
